title: 108_hr3491
content:
The Act is titled the "National Museum of African American History and Culture Act". Congress finds that the United States symbolizes democracy and freedom, with the legacy of African Americans deeply intertwined. There is no national museum within the Smithsonian dedicated to African American life, history, and culture, including key periods like slavery, Reconstruction, the Harlem Renaissance, and the civil rights movement. Establishing a National Museum of African American History and Culture would focus on collecting, preserving, and researching this important heritage. The National Museum of African American History and Culture would focus on collecting, preserving, researching, and exhibiting African American historical and cultural material. The National Museum of African American History and Culture, established by section 4, is defined in the Act along with terms like Board of Regents, Council, and Secretary. The National Museum of African American History and Culture is established within the Smithsonian Institution to collect, study, and exhibit African American life, art, history, and culture, including the periods of slavery, Reconstruction, Harlem Renaissance, civil rights movement, and other periods of the African American diaspora. It will also maintain permanent and temporary exhibits documenting the history of slavery and African American life, art, history, and culture, as well as collect artifacts and documents. The National Museum of African American History and Culture focuses on collecting, studying, and exhibiting artifacts and documents related to African American life, art, history, and culture. It also collaborates with other museums, educational institutions, and organizations to develop programs, manage collections, and train museum professionals. The National Museum of African American History and Culture collaborates with other institutions to develop programs and manage collections. SEC. 5. COUNCIL. The National Museum of African American History and Culture Council is established within the Smithsonian Institution. Its duties include making recommendations on museum planning, advising on administration, recommending budgets, reporting on acquisitions, and adopting bylaws for operation. The National Museum of African American History and Culture Council has the authority to acquire artifacts for the museum's collections, dispose of items to fund new acquisitions, and set criteria for the use of collections and resources related to African American history and culture in the United States. The National Museum of African American History and Culture Council is responsible for preserving and maintaining the museum's collections, accepting gifts for the museum's work, and is composed of 19 voting members including the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution and a member of the Board of Regents. The National Museum of African American History and Culture Council consists of 19 voting members, including one member appointed by the Board of Regents and seventeen individuals appointed based on recommendations from organizations and the Council. The initial appointments must be made within 180 days of the Act's enactment, and each appointed member serves a 3-year term. The National Museum of African American History and Culture Council consists of 19 voting members appointed for 1, 2, or 3-year terms. Members can be reappointed for a maximum of 2 terms, and vacancies do not affect the Council's powers. The Council members are appointed for specific terms and vacancies do not affect the Council's powers. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the appointed member serves for the remainder of the term. Council members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses for official duties. The Council elects a chairperson from its members by majority vote. Meetings are called by the chairperson or upon request of a majority of members, at least twice a year. During the first year, the Council must meet at least four times. A majority of voting members constitutes a quorum for conducting business. The Museum shall have a Director appointed by the Secretary, who will manage it under the policies of the Board of Regents. The Secretary may appoint two additional employees to serve under the Director, with pay not bound by certain provisions of the United States Code. Educational and liaison programs are also established. The Director of the Museum may carry out educational programs related to African American life, art, history, and culture, including digital and collaborative programs with schools. They shall consult with the Institute of Museum and Library Services for grant and scholarship programs. The Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services, in consultation with the Council and the Museum Director, will establish grant, internship, fellowship, and scholarship programs to support African American museums and individuals studying African American life, art, history, and culture. Additionally, there will be cooperation with other institutions to promote understanding of modern-day issues. The Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services will establish grant programs to support African American museums and individuals studying African American life, art, history, and culture. A grant program will allow an African-American museum to increase its endowment fund for educational programming and traveling exhibits. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding as needed for each fiscal year. The Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services will establish grant programs to support African American museums and individuals studying African American life, art, history, and culture, with necessary funding for each fiscal year thereafter. SEC. 8. BUILDING FOR THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY AND CULTURE. The Board of Regents must designate a site for the National Museum of African American History and Culture within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The designated site must be chosen from specific locations in the District of Columbia. The Banneker Overlook site on 10th Street Southwest is designated for the National Museum of African American History and Culture until the Board of Regents designates a permanent site. If the designated site is under a Federal agency's jurisdiction, it will be transferred to the Smithsonian Institution. The Board of Regents will consult with various entities regarding the transfer of jurisdiction over the designated site to the Smithsonian Institution. The committees involved in the transfer of jurisdiction over the designated site to the Smithsonian Institution are: 
- The Committee on Rules and Administration of the Senate
- The Committee on House Administration of the House of Representatives
- The Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives
- The Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives
- The Committee on Appropriations of the Senate The Board of Regents, in consultation with the Council, may plan, design, and construct a building for the Museum at the designated site. Chapter 89 of title 40, United States Code, does not apply to the Museum. The Board of Regents will share the costs of the project equally between Federal and non-Federal sources. Appropriations are authorized as needed. SEC. 9. Authority for contracts and payments under this Act is subject to appropriations in advance, except as provided in section 11(b).

SEC. 10. The Council and Board of Regents must consider reports and plans from the National Museum of African American History and Culture Plan for Action Presidential Commission.

SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for the Smithsonian Institution to carry out the Act, with $17,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for subsequent years. Funds remain available until expended and can be used for fundraising from private sources.
